results.title: Modern weather theory. Part 2. Structure of storms
results.brief_description: This film uses animation and maps to explain normal weather conditions and the atmosphere that creates the prevailing winds. Maps and diagrams also show the zones of the prevailing westerlies, and trade winds, and the way in which warm moist air rises, cools by expansion, loses its moisture by precipitation, and so on.

results.title: Modern France: the land and the people
results.brief_description: A brief geographical survey of modern France. Covers wheat farming in the North; flower gathering and orange growing on the Riviera; vineyards around Bordeaux; life at the port of Bordeaux; travel by barge on the Seine to Paris; the markets and shops of Paris; a steel-mill in Nancy.

results.title: The Modern electric refrigerator. Part 1. The How and why of refrigeration
results.creator_credit: David Cons, Frank A. Hoare, Film Producers Guild and Merton Park
results.brief_description: Describes the nature of food and explains how heat acts to cause decay and cold acts as a preservative. Explains three main processes of refrigeration - evaporation, pressure and condensation, and how these function in a sealed unit. Shows how to pack food for maximum efficiency and air circulation. Gives advice on defrosting, cleaning and care.

results.title: A Modern Egyptian family
results.creator_credit: Sam Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description: Focuses on the life of a middle class family in Egypt. It shows the warmth and hospitality of the family and its strong feeling for Islam, and it depicts the effects of modernisation on traditional family patterns.

results.title: Mission to no man's land
results.creator_credit: Georges Pessis, Stanley Wright, Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and Rank Screen Services
results.brief_description: A tour of a typical Austrian refugee camp, showing something of the extent of the problem. Yul Brynner records interviews with the refugees. One particularly moving sequence shows an elderly refugee talking on the long distance telephone with his family in the United States.

results.title: Minus 107
results.creator_credit: Garry Wapshott, Peter Leslie Lamb, Artransa Park Studios and Consolidated Film Producers
results.brief_description: A history of the old gold-mining town of Walhalla in Gippsland, Victoria. Today it is almost a ghost town. Economics forced the closing of the mines after World War I and successive fires have destroyed what was left of the wooden buildings. Features archival footage and stills of the Long Tunnel Mine, richest in Victoria, and the railway to Moe opened in 1910.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Garry Wapshott, Peter Leslie Lamb, Artransa Park Studios and Consolidated Film Producers

results.title: Millions for the finding
results.creator_credit: Hugh Alexander, Eric Thompson and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Survey of Australia’s mineral resources. Shows silver-lead-zinc mines at Broken Hill; copper-silver-lead-zinc mines at Mt Lyell in Tasmania; coal from the various mines of New South Wales; iron ore from South Australia and Yampi Sound to the blast furnaces at Newcastle, Port kembla and Whyalla; scheelite, from King Island in Bass Strait; oil from Exmouth Gulf, and radio-active minerals from Radium Hill. Modern methods of mineral detection are shown, including aerial surveying.

results.title: Millionaire for a pound
results.brief_description: A satirical impression without spoken commentary, of Surfers’ Paradise. Opening with colour shots of the idyllic countryside views approaching the town, the film quickly transfers to the gaudiness of the town itself with bizarre signs, neon lights and flashy flats. Features a tape-manipulated mouth organ and Beatniks! Rich with the iconography 60’s Australia, this is a fascinating document of the laconic, innocent charms that then characterised Australia’s favourite seaside idyll. Reminiscent of the surrealist social documentary work of Humphrey Jennings.

results.title: Mike and Stefani
results.creator_credit: R. Maslyn Williams and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Mike and Stefani, a young Ukrainian couple, spent World War II in German labour camps. After the war the couple were reunited and as two of the eight million “displaced persons” in European refugee camps they sought to resettle in Australia. The film had a twofold purpose, to counter the criticism within Australia that post-war immigration procedures for such people were inadequate and that some “undesirables” were slipping through the net, and to encourage Australians to accept the sudden influx of non-British immigrants in the immediate post-war years. Photographer: R.G. Pearse.
